dialogs.original: Mistress! What, mistress! Juliet!Fast, I warrant her, she.    Why, lamb! Why, lady! Fie, you slug-a-bed.    Why, love, I say. Madam! Sweet-heart! Why, bride!    What, not a word?   You take your pennyworths now.    Sleep for a week, for the next night, I warrant,    The County Paris hath set up his rest    That you shall rest but little.God forgive me,    Marry, and amen.   How sound is she asleep!    I must needs wake her.Madam, madam, madam!    Ay, let the county take you in your bed.    Hell fright you up, i faith. Will it not be?    [Opens the bed curtains]    What, dressed and in your clothes, and down again?    I must needs wake you. Lady, lady, lady!    Alas, alas! Help, help! My ladys dead!    Oh, welladay, that ever I was born!    Some aqua vitae, ho!My lord! My lady!
dialogs.translated: Mistress! Hey, mistress! Juliet! Fast asleep, I bet. Hey, lamb! Hey, lady! Hey, you sleepyhead! Hey, love, I say! Madam! Sweetheart! Hey, bride! What, not a single word to say? Enjoy this last bit of sleep now. Get a weeks worth of sleep, because tonight, I bet, Count Paris will make sure that you dont get much rest. God forgive me. Indeed, and amen. How sound asleep she is! I have to wake her. Madam, madam, madam! Yes, let the count take you in your bed. Hell wake you up, no doubt. Wont he? [Opens the bed curtains] What? Still dressed in your clothes but asleep. I must wake you. Lady, lady, lady! No, no! Help, help! My ladys dead! Oh curse the day I was born! Hey! Get me some brandy! My lord! My lady!

dialogs.original: What noise is here?
dialogs.translated: Whats with all the noise?

dialogs.original: O lamentable day!
dialogs.translated: Oh, terrible day!

dialogs.original: What is the matter?
dialogs.translated: Whats the matter?

dialogs.original: Look, look. O heavy day!
dialogs.translated: Look, look! Oh, what an awful day!

dialogs.original: O me, O me! My child, my only life,Revive, look up, or I will die with thee!Help, help! Call help.
dialogs.translated: Oh no, oh no! My child, my reason for being, come back! Look up, or Ill die with you! Help, help! Call for help.

dialogs.original: For shame, bring Juliet forth. Her lord is come.
dialogs.translated: For shame, get Juliet out here. Her bridegroom has arrived.

dialogs.original: Shes dead, deceased, shes dead. Alack the day!
dialogs.translated: Shes dead, deceased, dead. Curse the day!

dialogs.original: Alack the day. Shes dead, shes dead, shes dead!
dialogs.translated: Curse the day. Shes dead, shes dead, shes dead!

dialogs.original: Ha? Let me see her. Out, alas! Shes cold.    Her blood is settled, and her joints are stiff.    Life and these lips have long been separated.    Death lies on her like an untimely frost    Upon the sweetest flower of all the field.
dialogs.translated: What? Let me see her. No! Shes cold. Her blood has stopped, and her joints are stiff. Life left her body a long while ago. Death rests on her like an unexpected frost that killed the most beautiful flower.

dialogs.original: O lamentable day!
dialogs.translated: Oh terrible day!

dialogs.original: O woeful time.
dialogs.translated: Oh awful time!

dialogs.original: Death, that hath taen her hence to make me wail,Ties up my tongue and will not let me speak.
dialogs.translated: Death, which has taken her away to make me cry, ties up my tongue and will not let me speak.

dialogs.original: Come, is the bride ready to go to church?
dialogs.translated: Come, is the bride ready to go to church?

dialogs.original: Ready to go, but never to return.    O son! The night before thy wedding day    Hath death lain with thy wife. There she lies,    Flower as she was, deflowered by him.    Death is my son-in-law. Death is my heir.    My daughter he hath wedded. I will die,    And leave him all. Life, living, all is Deaths.
dialogs.translated: Shes ready to go, but not to return.

dialogs.original: Have I thought long to see this mornings face,And doth it give me such a sight as this?
dialogs.translated: Have I waited to see this morning for so long, only for it to look like this?

dialogs.original: Accursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day!    Most miserable hour that eer time saw    In lasting labor of his pilgrimage.    But one, poor one, one poor and loving child,    But one thing to rejoice and solace in,    And cruel death hath catched it from my sight!
dialogs.translated: Cursed, unhappy, wretched, hateful day! The most miserable hour that ever existed in all of time. I had just one child livingone poor child, one poor and loving child. Just one thing to rejoice and find comfort in. Now cruel Death has stolen her from my sight!

dialogs.original: O woe! O woeful, woeful, woeful day!    Most lamentable day, most woeful day    That ever, ever, I did yet behold!    O day, O day, O day, O hateful day!    Never was seen so black a day as this.    O woeful day, O woeful day!
dialogs.translated: Oh misery! Oh miserable, miserable, miserable day! The saddest day, most miserable day that I ever, ever saw! Oh day! Oh day! Oh day! Oh hateful day! There has never been a day as black as this one. Oh miserable day, Oh miserable day!

dialogs.original: Beguiled, divorcèd, wrongèd, spited, slain!    Most detestable Death, by thee beguiled,    By cruel, cruel thee quite overthrown!    O love! O life! Not life, but love in death.
dialogs.translated: She was tricked, divorced, wronged, spited, killed! Detestable Death tricked her. Cruel, cruel Death murdered her. Oh love! Oh life! There is no life because my love is dead.

dialogs.original: Despised, distressèd, hated, martyred, killed!    Uncomfortable time, why camest thou now    To murder, murder our solemnity?    O child, O child! My soul, and not my child!    Dead art thou! Alack, my child is dead,    And with my child my joys are buried.
dialogs.translated: Despised, distressed, hated, martyred, killed! Why did you come now, Death, to murder, murder our joy? Oh child! Oh child! My soul and not my child! You are dead! No! My child is dead. My child will be buried together with my joy.

dialogs.original: Peace, ho, for shame! Confusions cure lives not    In these confusions. Heaven and yourself    Had part in this fair maid. Now heaven hath all,    And all the better is it for the maid.    Your part in her you could not keep from death,    But heaven keeps his part in eternal life.    The most you sought was her promotion,    For twas your heaven she should be advanced.    And weep ye now, seeing she is advanced    Above the clouds, as high as heaven itself?    Oh, in this love, you love your child so ill    That you run mad, seeing that she is well.    Shes not well married that lives married long,    But shes best married that dies married young.    Dry up your tears and stick your rosemary    On this fair corse, and, as the custom is,    And in her best array, bear her to church.    For though some nature bids us all lament,    Yet natures tears are reasons merriment.
dialogs.translated: Quiet, for shame! Your outcries are no cure for confusion. Both you and heaven played a part in giving you your child. Now heaven has her, and she is better off. The part of her that came from you could not stop her from dying, but the part she got from heaven gives her eternal life. The most you could hope for her was that she marry well. Your idea of heaven for her was that she move up the social ladder. Yet now you weep, even though she has risen up above the clouds, all the way to heaven itself? Oh, by mourning her death you love your child so poorly, going crazy even though she is well and in heaven. It is better for a girl to die young while her marriage is still fresh and loving than to be married for a long time. Dry your tears, and place your rosemary on this beautiful corpse. And, as is the custom, put her in her finest clothes and carry her to church. Its human nature to shed tears, but reason says that we should be joyful.

dialogs.original: All things that we ordained festival    Turn from their office to black funeral.    Our instruments to melancholy bells,    Our wedding cheer to a sad burial feast.    Our solemn hymns to sullen dirges change,    Our bridal flowers serve for a buried corse,    And all things change them to the contrary.
dialogs.translated: The things that we prepared for the wedding now will be used instead for the funeral. Our musical instruments will be exchanged for mourning bells. Our wedding banquet will be a sad burial feast instead. Our celebratory hymns will change to sad funeral dirges. Our bridal flowers will cover a buried corpse. Everything will be used for the opposite purpose than we expected.

dialogs.original: Sir, go you in, and, madam, go with him;    And go, Sir Paris. Every one prepare    To follow this fair corse unto her grave.    The heavens do lour upon you for some ill.    Move them no more by crossing their high will.
dialogs.translated: Sir, you go in. Madam, go with him. And you too, Sir Paris. Everyone prepare to follow this beautiful corpse to her grave. The heavens hang over you for some unknown reason. Stop fighting heavens will, and it will no longer move against you.

dialogs.original: Faith, we may put up our pipes and be gone.
dialogs.translated: I guess we can put our pipes away and leave.

dialogs.original: Honest good fellows, ah, put up, put up,For, well you know, this is a pitiful case.
dialogs.translated: Honest good men, yes. Put them away, away. As you know, this is a sad case.

dialogs.original: Ay, by my troth, the case may be amended.
dialogs.translated: Yes, but this case at least can be mended.

dialogs.original: Musicians, O musicians, Hearts Ease, Hearts Ease.O, an you will have me live, play Hearts Ease.
dialogs.translated: Musicians, oh, musicians! Play Hearts Ease, Hearts Ease. Oh, if you want me to live, play Hearts Ease.

dialogs.original: Why Hearts ease?
dialogs.translated: Why Hearts Ease?

dialogs.original: O musicians, because my heart itself plays My Heart isFull. O, play me some merry dump to comfort me.
dialogs.translated: Oh, musicians, because my heart itself is playing My Heart is Full of Woe. Oh, play me some happy mournful tune to comfort me.

dialogs.original: Not a dump, we. Tis no time to play now.
dialogs.translated: No, we wont play a sad song. Now is not the time for it.

dialogs.original: You will not then?
dialogs.translated: You wont, then?

dialogs.original: No.
dialogs.translated: No.

dialogs.original: I will then give it you soundly.
dialogs.translated: Then Ill give you something you wont forget.

dialogs.original: What will you give us?
dialogs.translated: What will you give us?

dialogs.original: No money, on my faith, but the gleek. I will give you the minstrel.
dialogs.translated: Not money, I swear. But Ill insult you, and call you rogues.

dialogs.original: Then I will give you the serving creature.
dialogs.translated: Then Ill call you a lowly servant.

dialogs.original: Then will I lay the serving creatures dagger on your pate. I will carry no crotchets. Ill re you, Ill fa you. Do you note me?
dialogs.translated: Then Ill take my serving knife to smack you upside the head. I wont need to sing. Ill make you sing. Do you hear me?

dialogs.original: An you re us and fa us, you note us.
dialogs.translated: If you make us sing, youll hear us.

dialogs.original: Pray you, put up your dagger and put out your wit.
dialogs.translated: Please, put away your knife and show some wits.

dialogs.original: Then have at you with my wit. I will dry-beat you withan iron wit and put up my iron dagger. Answer me like men.    [Sings]  When griping grief the heart doth wound    And doleful dumps the mind oppress,    Then music with her silver sound     [Speaks]   Why silver sound? Why music with her silversound? What say you, Simon Catling?
dialogs.translated: Ill attack you with my wit! Ill put away my iron dagger and thrash you with my wicked wit. Answer me like men. [Singing]When grief wounds your heart,And sadness presses on your mind,Then music with her silver sound[Speaking] Why silver sound? What does  music with her silver sound mean? What do you say, Simon Catling?

dialogs.original: Marry, sir, because silver hath a sweet sound.
dialogs.translated: Well, sir, because silver has a sweet sound.

dialogs.original: Pretty.What say you, Hugh Rebeck?
dialogs.translated: A witty reply! What do you say, Hugh Rebeck?

dialogs.original: I say, silver sound because musicians sound for silver.
dialogs.translated: I say silver sound, because musicians play music to earn silver.

dialogs.original: Pretty too.What say you, James Soundpost?
dialogs.translated: More wit! What do you say, James Soundpost?

dialogs.original: Faith, I know not what to say.
dialogs.translated: Well, I dont know what to say.

dialogs.original: Oh, I cry you mercy, you are the singer. I will say for you. It is music with her silver sound because musicians have no gold for sounding.    [Sings]  Then music with her silver sound    With speedy help doth lend redress.
dialogs.translated: Oh, I beg your pardon. Youre the singer. Ill answer for you. It is music with her silver sound, because musicians will never get rich.[Singing]Then music with her silver soundQuickly makes you feel all right.

dialogs.original: What a pestilent knave is this same!
dialogs.translated: What an annoying fool this man is!

dialogs.original: Hang him, jack! Come, we'll in here, tarry for the mourners, and stay dinner.
dialogs.translated: Oh, let him hang, man! Come with me, we'll go in here, wait for the mourners, and stay for dinner.
